channel.title: Infinite binary decimals (fractions) & strange properties
channel.description:
Just have a few things I've been trying to understand and I need some help.
The first thing, I noticed on the way home, is that .8^5 = .32768, which is the same number as 2^15 (and 8^5) which is 32,768. What about decimals determines whether or not a decimal exponent will be the same with an appended decimal at the beginning? I know the numbers .32768 and 32,768 have nothing in common besides the fact that they are represented similarly in base 10, but I'm trying to understand what could produce a result like this in the first place. Does it have to do with (1-.2)^5, or something else that gives it an easier binary representation/calculation?
When I was trying to solve this, I ran into my second question, which relates to how many decimals have an infinite representation in binary. I was trying to understand how the representation of .8 in binary could be related to the representation of 8, but it turns out .8 is a repeating decimal (.1[1001...]) How can this be summed as a series to make it 1/2 (the .1) + .3 as the remainder [to equal .8]? I couldn't solve this sum, though wolframalpha was able to get the correct result of .3:
sum from 1 to infinity of (1/(2^(4n-2))+1/(2^(4n+1)))
I tried summing as an integral and got a very incorrect answer and wasn't sure where I went wrong. I ended with (1/4log2)*(1/[2^2) + 1/[2^5]) = , if that helps for comparison. That equals like .04 though so it's very wrong, I'm just not sure how.
Thanks for anyone who tries to help. I don't currently have any math classes or know any math professors yet at uni so I wasn't sure who to ask these questions

item.title: Infinite binary decimals (fractions) & strange properties
item.dc:creator: @eyeownyew Eyeownyew
item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:4, topic:552378”]1. It depends on the exponent entirely. Numbers below and equal to a certain value will contain 0s in front of it, but numbers greater than that value raised to the exponent won’t have 0s in front. The number ignoring the leading 0s is the same regardless because you can rewrite each decimal as a form of scientific notation so you’re really applying the exponents to the same numbers but dealing with different 10s. You can calculate that certain value by doing using the expression .09999999… ^ (1 / n) where n is the exponent (Don’t ask me how I found this; it was annoying :P)

2. Looks like if the number can be multiplied by a power-of-2 and return a whole number, the result is finite. Otherwise, it’s infinite. For example, .25, .5, .75, .125, .375, .8125, etc… (basically 1/2, 1/4, 3/4, 1/8, 3/8, 13/16) are all finite results. This one was actually pretty easy to figure out.[/quote]
Thanks for the response

  1. That’s very interesting. I suppose the bit with scientific notation makes sense
  2. I meant I couldn’t find a way to actually calculate it. I’m able to understand the logic behind it, but actually doing it feels difficult.

Read full topic

item.title: Infinite binary decimals (fractions) & strange properties
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

1. It depends on the exponent entirely. Numbers below and equal to a certain value will contain 0s in front of it, but numbers greater than that value raised to the exponent won’t have 0s in front. The number ignoring the leading 0s is the same regardless because you can rewrite each decimal as a form of scientific notation so you’re really applying the exponents to the same numbers but dealing with different 10s. You can calculate that certain value by doing using the expression .09999999… ^ (1 / n) where n is the exponent (Don’t ask me how I found this; it was annoying :P)

2. Looks like if the number can be multiplied by a power-of-2 and return a whole number, the result is finite. Otherwise, it’s infinite. For example, .25, .5, .75, .125, .375, .8125, etc… (basically 1/2, 1/4, 3/4, 1/8, 3/8, 13/16) are all finite results. This one was actually pretty easy to figure out.

Read full topic

Stop trolling us!
